title: 106_hr515
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Child Handgun Injury Prevention Act". The Congress finds that in the 10 years from 1987 through 1996, nearly 2,200 children in the United States aged 14 or younger died from unintentional shootings. The United States leads in rates of children lost to unintentional firearms-related death compared to other industrialized countries. Additionally, the number of nonfatal unintentional firearm injuries treated in U.S. hospital emergency rooms annually is nearly 8 times the number of deaths. In 25 other industrialized countries, the number of unintentional deaths from firearms is 9 times greater than in the United States. A study found that children as young as 3 years old are capable of firing most commercially available handguns. Children as young as 3 years old have the finger strength to fire most commercially available handguns. Currently, firearms are not subject to minimum safety standards in the United States, despite public support for regulation. Trigger locks and safety devices are often inadequate in preventing accidental firearm discharges. Firearms and safety locks move in interstate commerce. Many trigger locks are inadequate in preventing accidental firearm discharges or children from accessing firearms. Regulation of handgun discharge protection products. The Secretary of the Treasury is required to regulate handgun discharge protection products to reduce the risk of injury to children. The regulations must establish a minimum safety standard for these products, ensuring they are of high quality and cannot be easily removed from a handgun. The Secretary of the Treasury must create a standard for handgun discharge protection products to prevent children from operating a handgun. The standard should ensure quality and restrict removal without specific access methods. Test protocols for poison prevention packaging may be considered. The standard must be issued within 12 months and take effect 6 months after issuance. SEC. 4. ORDERS; INSPECTIONS. The Secretary has the authority to issue orders prohibiting the manufacture, sale, transfer, or delivery of handgun discharge protection products that violate the Act. They can also require manufacturers and dealers to provide notice of associated risks and how to mitigate them. The Secretary can take various actions to ensure compliance with the Act, including bringing products into conformity, repairing or replacing them, issuing refunds, recalling products, or submitting a plan for implementation. Additionally, inspections may be conducted to verify compliance with regulations. The Secretary may recall products or request a plan for compliance. Inspections can be conducted at manufacturing facilities and during transportation of handgun discharge protection products. SEC. 5. UNLAWFUL ACTS. It will be illegal for licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers to sell handguns without the required discharge protection product. There is an exception for sales to government agencies. SEC. 6. WARNING LABELS FOR HANDGUNS. SEC. 6. WARNING LABELS FOR HANDGUNS. A licensed manufacturer, importer, or dealer must include a warning label on handgun packaging and materials, stating the dangers of children accessing and operating handguns. The label must emphasize the importance of keeping handguns locked and unloaded to prevent accidents. The warning label required for handguns must be in contrast with other printed materials on the package, and it should be affixed to the handgun when transferred without packaging. This section will take effect 60 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS.

Licensed manufacturers, importers, and dealers must report any information indicating a child's unintentional or self-inflicted gunshot wound from a handgun they sold after the Act's effective date, resulting in death, serious injury, or medical treatment.

SEC. 8. ENFORCEMENT. The Secretary can impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for violations of the Act, revoke federal firearms licenses for violations, and individuals can bring a private cause of action for damages in court. Private enforcement of the Act allows any interested person to bring a lawsuit in federal court to enforce the Act or stop any violations. The court may award attorney's fees to the prevailing party. Compliance with the Act does not excuse liability under common law or state statutes. (e) Effect on Private Remedies: Compliance with this Act or any order issued under it does not exempt anyone from liability under common law or State statutory law. The Secretary's failure to take action authorized under this Act is not admissible in litigation. Criminal penalties may apply to those who knowingly violate provisions of this Act regarding handgun discharge protection products. SEC. 9. NO EFFECT ON STATE LAW. This Act does not affect State laws unless they are inconsistent with this Act and provide greater protection to children in relation to handguns. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 10. DEFINITIONS. This section defines terms such as "handgun discharge protection product," "children," "licensed importer," "licensed manufacturer," "licensed dealer," "Secretary," and "handgun" as used in the Act.
